screens.headline: Why pay $2,500 when you could pay $500?
screens.text: Spreads let you trade options for a fraction of the cost. But there's a catch...

screens.headline: A spread = Two options working together
screens.text: A spread is when you BUY one option and SELL another option at the same time. Think of it like trading a 'pair' instead of singles. The option you sell reduces the cost of the option you buy.

screens.headline: Insurance with a deductible
screens.text: Imagine buying car insurance. Full coverage costs $2,000/year (like buying a call). But if you add a $5,000 deductible, it drops to $500/year (like selling a higher call to reduce cost). You're still covered for big moves, but you accept limits on your max payout. That's exactly how spreads work.

reveal_sections.label: Full insurance = Naked option (expensive)
reveal_sections.content: Buying a single option without selling one gives you unlimited profit potential but costs more.

reveal_sections.label: Deductible = Selling second leg (cheaper)
reveal_sections.content: Selling another option brings in premium that reduces your net cost.

reveal_sections.label: Limited payout = Capped profit
reveal_sections.content: The option you sold caps your maximum profit, but you paid less to enter the trade.

cards.definition: The two options in a spread (long leg + short leg)
You pay money upfront (spread costs you)
You collect money upfront (spread pays you)

screens.question: If you buy a $50 call for $8 and sell a $55 call for $3, what's your net cost?
screens.explanation_correct: Perfect! You paid $8 and collected $3, so $8 - $3 = $5 net debit. You spent $5 per share ($500 per spread).
screens.explanation_wrong: Not quite. When you BUY ($8) and SELL ($3), you subtract: $8 - $3 = $5. Since you paid more than you collected, it's a debit.

screens.question: Why would someone sell an option as part of their spread?
options: To reduce the cost of the option they're buying
screens.explanation_correct: Exactly! The premium you collect from selling reduces your upfront cost. You give up some upside, but you lower your entry price significantly.
screens.explanation_wrong: The main reason is cost reduction. Selling an option brings in premium, which offsets the cost of the option you bought. The trade-off is capped profit.

screens.headline: Build your first spread
screens.description: Adjust the short call strike to see how it affects cost and profit potential
teaching_points: Notice: Selling the $105 call gives you $8 back, reducing your $12 cost to just $4
But your max profit is now capped at $1 ($100 total) instead of unlimited
Try different strikes to see the cost/profit trade-off

cards.back: Buying AND selling options simultaneously. Two legs working together as one position.
Reduce cost by 50-80% compared to naked options. Trade-off: Capped profit potential.
Max Profit = Width - Debit | Max Loss = Debit | Breakeven = Long Strike + Debit
